Last year, a United Nations report on climate change essentially punted on one of the most important questions; that is, how much will sea level rise in the next century as a result of global warming?
The panel said there was simply not enough data to answer that question.
Since then, scientists have been circulating all sorts of guesstimates, and some are extremely high.
Now a new study brings a dose of reality, as NPR's Richard Harris reports.
The real problem in gauging future sea level rise is scientists don't have a good idea about how quickly the giant glaciers in Greenland and Antarctica can ooze out into the sea.
They hold huge potential for sea-level rise, but ice can only flow so fast.
But without really good computer models to calculate that flow, Tad Pfeffer at the University of Colorado says scientists are often just guessing.
He says he was at a scientific meeting where someone just threw out a number, that surging glaciers from Greenland alone will increase sea levels by six feet this century.
And I said, where did that number come from?
It turns out that numbers like this are just floating around, not anchored in science.
And I said, okay, well let's imagine that Greenland does raise the sea level by two meters in the next century.
What would have to happen if that were to occur?
The question really comes down to how fast ice can flow over and around the rocks that currently hold it back.
I would also hope that we would recognize that we have, for a long time, been making inadequate investments in activities that could lessen the impact of disasters such as this.
There was also criticism from Republicans.
Majority Whip Ray Blunt said he agreed with President Bush that the results of relief efforts have not been satisfactory.
Hard lessons have been learned.
Tragic lessons have been learned, I hope, but I hope lessons have been learned that we have to respond more quickly.
We have to respond in the right ways and be sure our priorities are right.
The sharpest complaints, though, came today from members of the Congressional Black Caucus.
Diane Watson is a California Democrat.
Shame, shame on America.
We were put to the test, and we have failed.
And this goes right to the leadership of our House.
Watson pointed to Speaker of the House Dennis Hastert's published remarks yesterday in which he questioned whether it makes sense to rebuild New Orleans as it was.
Hastert was not at the House session today.
He was in Indiana, at a campaign fund-raiser.
But Majority Whip Blunt came to his defense.

I think the speaker was much--was very clear that he understands this is a discussion that needs to have lots of input, and that input is going to be most valuable the closer it is to home, and I mean those homes.
Blunt said the speaker had done what he needed to do, get the emergency bill to the floor and on its way to be signed by the president.
David Welna, NPR News, the Capitol.
And you can read NPR's Weblog tracking the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina at our Web site, npr.org.
It's been about six months since the Bush administration decided to let Lehman Brothers collapse.
The downfall of the global financial services firm was one of the first of a series of implosions on Wall Street.
Now, hundreds of Lehman employees find themselves searching for work in this grim new world.
One of them is Spencer Cutter.
He was a senior vice president.
He worked for Lehman Brothers for nine years.
He is now a contributor to the Wall Street Journal's blog, Laid Off and Looking.
He joins us from New York, and Spencer, it's been about a year since you were let go.
How's your job search going?
It's going, it's a bit frustrating.
You know, there's - there are jobs out there but the competition level is extremely high.
And there are no jobs at all for the type of work I used to do specifically, so anything that is out there is going to be to at least some degree a career change.

And in this type of environment, even though there are certain transferable skills it would require, you know, three to six months or so to kind of get up the curve, and people don't feel very open to that sort of prospect right now.
And I'm curious, when you tell people that you came from Lehman, does that create any sort of reaction, either way, positively or negatively?
I haven't personally run into it yet.
I have heard a lot of people - secondhand have told me that they've heard some negative reactions.
I have gotten a few comments on the blog that people seemed to think that because I worked at Lehman I'm personally responsible for the financial crisis that the whole country is in.
In one of your blogs, you write about how you used to value your life in terms of your number, your targeted liquid net worth.
But you say you've had a change of heart.
When and how did that happen?
I'm just - I'm going through a reassessment process for my whole life and what is it that I want to do, who do I want to be for the next five, 10, 20 years.
Who do you want to be?
What do you want to do next?
You know, I have my ideal of what I'd like to do.
I'm not sure that that's available, you know.
What I wanted to do when I left Lehman Brothers and what I still have held out some hope of eventually being able to do is some sort of investment management.
I've got lots of finance skills.
I don't really want to go back to investment banking, but I'd like to be able to do something that can leverage my finance skills in the future.
So, investment management or I had the hope of working for the Federal Reserve.
I thought that would be an interesting opportunity.
One of the things I wanted to do once I got out of investment banking was to get into the wine business.
But something long-term that I can do for 10 years, 20 years, and have a little bit of a life - work-life balance, which you didn't have in investment banking.
If I might ask, the tone of your blog is pretty upbeat, pretty optimistic.
Right now, I have to say, you maybe don't sound as optimistic as you do in your blog.
Are there ever days where it's just tough to be hopeful?
Yes.

It's particularly hard when you do find that rare opportunity where someone has said, yes, I do want to interview you for this position, and you get very excited because here's, you know, the needle in the haystack.
You may have finally found it.
And somebody's expressed interest in you and sort of witted you out of what I'm sure thousands of applications they're getting in this environment.
And you can't help but get your hopes up a little bit that it will work out.

And I've gone through that, you know, dozens of times now in the last six to 12 months and you know, it's always turned out that there's somebody else who's more experienced in that particular area that they're hiring for, so I haven't gotten the job.
So there are days when you find out that you didn't get the job that you were really hoping to get - those are the toughest ones.
You can't help but you have to just kind of pick yourself up and move on.
You're not going to get anywhere just sort of milling around and sitting on the sofa watching ""Hogan's Heroes"" all afternoon.
So you got - you kind of don't have a choice but to keep going.
Former Lehman Brothers executive Spencer Cutter is blogging for the Wall Street Journal's online series, ""Laid Off and Looking."" Thanks, Spencer, and good luck.
Thank you.
Guatemala's president elect is a 63-year-old conservative who once ran the country's prison system.

Katrina struck as Germany was in the midst of an election campaign.
While some politicians have been accused of trying to exploit the American tragedy, many Germans do feel that US policy is to blame for the scope of the disaster.
Constanze Stelzenmuller of the German Marshall Fund says many Germans associate Katrina with global warming.
In the public mind, certainly in Europe, there is a connection.
And I think people would be expecting America to react differently to climate change issues after Katrina.
The Marshall Fund did a trans-Atlantic study before Katrina.
It found that 71 percent of Americans feel more likely to be personally affected by terrorism than by other global threats.
Among Europeans, 73 percent put global warming at the top of the list.
Now international pressure will surely mount for the Bush administration to take climate change seriously and reconsider its boycott of the Kyoto protocol on limiting greenhouse gas emissions.
That pressure could begin as early as Wednesday when President Bush encounters more than 170 foreign leaders at the UN General Assembly meeting in New York.
For NPR News, I'm Jerome Socolovsky in Madrid.
Technology has always driven the way we cook; not always for the better--think the microwave.
But a new generation of chefs is using equipment you'd never imagine to forge what they consider a new cuisine.
Call it special-effects food.
You can get a sampling at a new restaurant in Chicago's trendy Lincoln Park neighborhood; it's called Alinea.
And we thought we'd take you there, since it's hard to spot if you're just strolling down North Halsted Street.
Is there a sign out front?
Did I miss it?
No. No.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But that's the point.
That's--you know, that's the whole thing.
It's like, you know, when you go by, you see this kind of dark facade with this kind of covelike entry, and it's just--it's supposed to just...
If you don't know what's there, just walk on by.
Right, right.
You have to be looking for us.
That's Alinea's chef, Grant Achatz.
He sat down with us just before the doors opened one recent evening, while staff did some last-minute vacuuming and laid out menus on an elegant sideboard.
Like everything here, the menus are minimalist: no prices, no description, just a series of words.
One entree reads `Bison, beets, blueberries, burning cinnamon.'
Burning cinnamon?
We plate the food composition on a plate, and then off to the side, we have a very small dish that we ignite cinnamon sticks until they're burning embers.
We blow them out until they start to smolder, we put them in this little dish, we put a lid on it and then it goes on the plate.

So the plate comes out, gets sat down in front of the guest, the server pulls off the lid of this little dish and the wafts of sweet, smoky cinnamon kind of surround the guests and they take that in while they're eating the dish.
